parts.fpdescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 27 bis r. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 1r. Opening of Aristotle’s Peri Hermeneias (On Interpretation) in the translation of Boethius. You may recognize this page from the teaser of this exhibition. Aristotle’s On Interpretation deals with the relationship between words, reality and logic. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v: At the top of the scheme we find ‘Usia’ , meaning substance, a Latinised form of the Greek οὐσία. Cicero is given as the example of ‘man’. Paris, BnF, MS lat. 12949, f. 24v. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 12r: Introduction (accessus) to the author, Augustine, and an etymology of the word dialectica, with a reference to John Scot Eriugenia. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 12r: Opening of De dialectica, with the well-known opening words: “Dialectia est bene disputandi scientia”; “Dialectic is the art of arguing well. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 25v: ‘Heiricus magister Remigii fecit has glossas’. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 46r: opening of Porphyry’s Isagoge, an introduction to the Categories of Aristotle. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 52v: ‘We should not accept this gloss’ - ‘Non est haec glossa a nobis recipienda.’ https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v: At the top of the scheme we find ‘Usia’ , meaning substance, a Latinised form of the Greek οὐσία. Cicero is given as the example of ‘man’. Paris, BnF, MS lat. 12949, f. 24v. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v
Paris, BnF, lat. 12963, f. 8v (detail). Cassiodorus, Institutiones. Ms. from Corbie, second half of the 10th century. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b105442152

Paris, BnF, lat. 14614, ff. 117-202 (the opening of the text is missing). Date: 12th century. The manuscript belonged to the library of St. Victor, Paris. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b6000788f

Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 69r: a column for commentary on the left of the tekst, and two columns on the right. The lower margin is also typically large to house large amounts of notes and comments. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525

Paris, BnF, lat. 7749, f. 33v: Victorinus’s commentary included a number of summary diagrams. Cicero’s text is added in red in the margins. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b8530356j

Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 37r: A hand, leg or arm (?) and face on fol. 37r. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 49v: A head and peculiar animal on fol. 49v. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 18r: In manuscripts, marginal notes are used to (1) call attention to certain things. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986

Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 58r: You can see that the material was already damaged when the scribe was copying the commentary into the margins: he/she deals with the damages parchment and the hole in it. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986
Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail): Square of opposition. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1617684
Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail): Square of opposition. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1617684
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 63r: List of propositions. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 89v: The scheme begins with two examples of simple propositions which do not ‘convert’: ‘Plato is a philosopher’ ‘Virtue is good’ These syllogisms cannot be converted by simply swopping the subject and predicate terms. ‘A philosopher’ is not necessarily Plato! Similarly, virtue is not the only ‘good’. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 89v: Here the scheme represents Boethius’ account of ‘conversion by opposition’ (‘contraposition’) The second set of propositions: ‘Omnis non homo animal est. Omne animal non homo est.’ (’All non-man is an animal; all animals are not man’) shows how switching the order of the subject and predicate of the sentence generates a new proposition. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 90v: Ch(arles): How many species are there in dialectic? A(lcuin): The most important are 5: ‘isagogae’, categories, syllogistic formulas and definitions, ‘topica’, and ‘perermeniae’. Ch: What are ‘isagogae’? A: Isagoge is the (Greek) word for Latin ‘introductio’, ‘introduction’. Ch: What does ‘introduction’ mean? A: Introduction is … . http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 90v: Ch: What is ‘genus’? A: ‘Genus’ is what can be divided into species: it describes whatever you are investigating in an inclusive word, such as ‘animal’. For each individual species - man, horse, ox, lion etc. – ‘animal’ is the genus and is applied to them all. Ch: What is ‘species’? A: ‘Species’ is …. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 103v: A medieval reader has added a content list at the end of the volume, starting with ‘libri boetius’, books of Boethius, and listing the titles. These match the existing contents of BPL 84, so we know that this collection of texts has been together since at least the time it was in this reader’s hands. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84: On f. 8v we find the quire signature ‘c’, suggesting that this gathering of leaves was once the third in a collection. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 32v: An example of numbers (‘ii’), from f. 32v. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 13r: ‘Retro in libro topicorum iii’: ‘Back in book III of the Topics’. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 14r: ‘Retro in fine libri tercium topicorum ciceronis’: ‘Back in the end of the third book of Cicero’s Topics’. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 44v: two sets of rubrics (written in red) indicate that one text has ended and that another will begin on the next page. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 8r: a decorated initial is used for the first word of a new text. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84: Furthermore, a new set of quire gatherings starts on f. 17r; from this point to the end of the manuscript quires are numbered with numbers, not letters. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 88, f. 2v: Ninth-century script. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2028417
Leiden, UB, BPL 88, f. 2v: Eleventh-centruy additions. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2028417
Leiden, UB, BPL 88, f. 2r: Square of opposition. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2028417
f.94r Opening of Priscian's De Constructione with initial of Lady Grammar
f.143r The opening of the Pseudo-Ciceronian Rhetorica ad Herennium
f.166r The opening of Boethius’ translation of Porphyry’s Isagoge

Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 29 (878), p. 165: Manuscripts were often ruled with a knife; here we can see on p. 165 that the blade has cut through the parchment while ruling the edge of the text block. https://www.e-codices.unifr.ch/en/list/one/sbe/0029

Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 29 (878), p. 166: This passage of annotation gives us a clue about the kind of readers Cod. 29 (878) was expected to receive. As the first word, ‘ordo’, suggests, this gloss amounts to a reordering of the first words of Porphyry’s text (‘Cum sit necessarium...’). Glosses of this type helped medieval students make sense of Latin, and suggest that this copy of the Isagoge was prepared for an elementary readership. https://www.e-codices.unifr.ch/en/list/one/sbe/0029
Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315 (605), p. 139: representation of Porphyry’s five predicables. https://www.e-codices.unifr.ch/en/list/one/sbe/0315
Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315(605), p.6: The text has been carefully corrected, here ‘ad’ has been corrected to ‘ab’ and ‘actenus’ to ‘hactenus’. http://www.e-codices.ch/en/sbe/0315

Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315(605), p. 6: Here small squiggles have been added in the margin alongside the text; these are rudimentary quotation marks indicating original text from the Isagoge, the subject of Boethius’ commentary. http://www.e-codices.ch/en/sbe/0315

Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315(605), p. 6: Here interlinear glosses have been added to provide Latin equivalents of the Greek terms hyperbaton (transposition of words) and zeuma (where one word can be used in two different contexts). The glossator describes these as ‘confusus ordo’, the confusion of order, and ‘repetitio’, repetition, respectively. http://www.e-codices.ch/en/sbe/0315
St. Gallen, SB, Cod. Sang. 128, p. 3: The passage about Marcella. https://www.e-codices.unifr.ch/en/list/one/csg/0128
St. Gallen, Stiftsbibliothek, Cod.Sang. 273 (145 x 125mm). https://www.e-codices.unifr.ch/en/list/one/csg/0273

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, opening ff. 68v-69r. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 13v: Here the glossator introduces the characters in the conversation. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 13v: ‘Ecce’, ‘Look’, the glossator writes – ‘an example of induction’ . http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 13v: The glossator indicates who is speaking between the lines (‘Aspasia’s words’, ’Xenophon’s wife responds’ etc). These names and characters may have been unfamiliar to the reader, so these cues helped them follow the text. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 11r: These schemata summarise Cicero’s discussion of the aspects of human nature (De inventione, I.XXIV.35) which are used to describe people involved in a case. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 58v: a glossator adds Augustine’s list of the eight categories of lies (De mendacio, 25). http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135

Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v: The other scribe added a note on musical pitches, and two sets of schemes regarding syllogistic propositions. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v: A line separates the sets of examples of syllogisms. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v: We know who one of these scribes was – Rather of Verona (890-974) added a copy of a letter at the base of the page. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 31r: example of a very full commentary added in the margin. The book is 307 mm high. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282

Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v (detail): In the second set of schemes lines connect terms of the propositions and conclusion in order to indicate how the argument is constructed. Visualising the argument in this way helps understand why it is valid. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282

Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v (detail): The scheme is evidence of a reader trying to understand the steps made by Dialectic in reaching this conclusion; the scheme illustrates the reader’s thought process! http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282

Leiden, UB, BPL 88, f. 4v: Text in the box, drawn by us: ‘According to Calcidius, entelechy is perfecta aetas, completed lifetime. According to Aristotle, it is interpreted as absolute perfection. Plato, on the other hand, says that entelechy is the anima mundi, the soul of the world.’ http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2028417

parts.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 37r: Along the edges of the pages we find heads, hands and here even feet, pointing at passages in the text. When leafing through the manuscript, important passages thus pop out.

parts.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 11r (detail): ‘Rara est adeo concordia formae atque pudicitiae’: ‘Beauty rarely coincides with chastity’ (Juvenal, Satires, 10.295) – gloss to De inventione I.XXIV.35, where Cicero notes that a person could be either handsome or ugly.
parts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 11r (detail): ‘Rara est adeo concordia formae atque pudicitiae’: ‘Beauty rarely coincides with chastity’ (Juvenal, Satires, 10.295) – gloss to De inventione I.XXIV.35, where Cicero notes that a person could be either handsome or ugly.

parts.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 41v (detail): ‘Facilius est commendare paupertatem quam sustinere’: ‘It is easier to praise poverty than to put up with it’. The quotation is attributed to ‘Seneca’ and paraphrases Seneca the Elder’s Controversiae II.18. The passage glosses the question of appropriate reward for virtuous acts (De inventione, II.XXXIX.115)
parts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 41v (detail): ‘Facilius est commendare paupertatem quam sustinere’: ‘It is easier to praise poverty than to put up with it’. The quotation is attributed to ‘Seneca’ and paraphrases Seneca the Elder’s Controversiae II.18. The passage glosses the question of appropriate reward for virtuous acts (De inventione, II.XXXIX.115)

parts.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 70r (detail): ‘Nichil est iniquius his qui nusquam putant esse subtilitatem nisi ubi nihil est praeter subtilitatem’: ‘Nothing is more unfair than to think that acuteness is only present when there is nothing present but acuteness’. Quoting again from Seneca the Elder (Controversiae, I.21, trans. Winterbottom, LCL 463, p. 21), the quotation glosses Rhetorica ad Herennium II.XI.16, which concerns the dangers of ambiguous oratory.
parts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 70r (detail): ‘Nichil est iniquius his qui nusquam putant esse subtilitatem nisi ubi nihil est praeter subtilitatem’: ‘Nothing is more unfair than to think that acuteness is only present when there is nothing present but acuteness’. Quoting again from Seneca the Elder (Controversiae, I.21, trans. Winterbottom, LCL 463, p. 21), the quotation glosses Rhetorica ad Herennium II.XI.16, which concerns the dangers of ambiguous oratory.

parts.foliodescription: West door, Cathedral of Chartres, c. 1150. The throne of wisdom, framed by the liberal arts. The complex iconographical program is believed to have been designed by the scholar Thierry of Chartres, chancellor of the cathedral school from 1141 to c. 1155. Famous twelfth-century scholars such as William of Conches and Gilbert of Poitiers studied in Chartres.
parts.fpdescription: West door, Cathedral of Chartres, c. 1150. The throne of wisdom, framed by the liberal arts. The complex iconographical program is believed to have been designed by the scholar Thierry of Chartres, chancellor of the cathedral school from 1141 to c. 1155. Famous twelfth-century scholars such as William of Conches and Gilbert of Poitiers studied in Chartres.

parts.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 2r: Affirmative and Negative Propositions. In this example, the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’, is placed at the top left of the square. It’s placed alongside the other universal, but negative, proposition: ‘no men are just.’ At the bottom of the square we find the particular affirmative and particular negative propositions: ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’
parts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 2r: Affirmative and Negative Propositions. In this example, the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’, is placed at the top left of the square. It’s placed alongside the other universal, but negative, proposition: ‘no men are just.’ At the bottom of the square we find the particular affirmative and particular negative propositions: ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’

parts.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 2r: Contradictory Relationships. The diagonal lines crossing the centre of the diagram (labelled ‘contradictoriae’) connect propositions which are contradictory to each other. For example, if ‘all men are just’ (the universal affirmative proposition) then ‘some men are not just’ (the particular negative proposition) is a contradictory statement. If ‘all men are just’ then the statement ‘some men are not just’ cannot be true. Similarly, reading across the other diagonal, if ‘no men are just’ then the proposition ‘some men are just’ cannot be true.’
parts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 2r: Contradictory Relationships. The diagonal lines crossing the centre of the diagram (labelled ‘contradictoriae’) connect propositions which are contradictory to each other. For example, if ‘all men are just’ (the universal affirmative proposition) then ‘some men are not just’ (the particular negative proposition) is a contradictory statement. If ‘all men are just’ then the statement ‘some men are not just’ cannot be true. Similarly, reading across the other diagonal, if ‘no men are just’ then the proposition ‘some men are just’ cannot be true.’

parts.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 2r: Contradictory Relationships. The placement of the universal affirmative and negative propositions at the top of the square and the particular affirmative and negative propositions at the bottom is also meaningful; these are described as being ‘contrary’ to each other. That is, it is not possible for both of the universal propositions – ‘all men are just’ and ‘all men are not just’ – to be true, although they could be both false. However, while it is possible for both particular propositions – ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’ – to be true, they cannot both be false.
parts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 2r: Contradictory Relationships. The placement of the universal affirmative and negative propositions at the top of the square and the particular affirmative and negative propositions at the bottom is also meaningful; these are described as being ‘contrary’ to each other. That is, it is not possible for both of the universal propositions – ‘all men are just’ and ‘all men are not just’ – to be true, although they could be both false. However, while it is possible for both particular propositions – ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’ – to be true, they cannot both be false.

parts.foliodescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 2r: Contradictory Relationships. Finally, reading alongside the side of the square, a further relationship between the propositions, that of subalternation, is identified. If the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’ (placed at the top of the square), is true, then the corresponding particular affirmative proposition, ‘some men are just’ (placed at the bottom of the square), must also be true. Similarly, if the universal negative proposition, ‘no man is just’, then the particular negative proposition, ‘some man is not just’, must also be true.’
parts.fpdescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 2r: Contradictory Relationships. Finally, reading alongside the side of the square, a further relationship between the propositions, that of subalternation, is identified. If the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’ (placed at the top of the square), is true, then the corresponding particular affirmative proposition, ‘some men are just’ (placed at the bottom of the square), must also be true. Similarly, if the universal negative proposition, ‘no man is just’, then the particular negative proposition, ‘some man is not just’, must also be true.’

parts.foliodescription: Amsterdam, Allard Pierson, UBA, hs. I D 2: Formerly chained book, made in the twelfth century. In the fifteenth century this book was chained, using the ring on the right, in the city library of Amsterdam. Although it was rebound in the seventeenth century, the new binding incorporated the original ring.
parts.fpdescription: Amsterdam, Allard Pierson, UBA, hs. I D 2: Formerly chained book, made in the twelfth century. In the fifteenth century this book was chained, using the ring on the right, in the city library of Amsterdam. Although it was rebound in the seventeenth century, the new binding incorporated the original ring.
